General Construction 3. 2.1 General Painting Works 3. 2.2 Painting Process The painting process may be omitted with the approval of the design documents or the responsible person. 3. 2.3 Paint Mixing (1) Paint mixing shall refer to the submitted paint specifications, and only dedicated thinners shall be used. (2) When applying eco-friendly (reducing environmental load) products, the mixing ratio may be adjusted with the approval of the responsible personnel. 3. 2.4 Drying Time The drying time (film curing time) is the minimum time until the next process under a temperature of approximately 20℃ and a humidity of approximately 75%. When the temperature and humidity conditions vary significantly, the drying time shall be determined with the approval of the responsible personnel. 3. The standard amount of paint refers to the quantity of paint applied to a unit area of a flat surface. However, the actual amount used should be adjusted with extra allowance, considering the condition of the surface being painted and any paint loss. 3. "2.6 Opening Attendance and Paint Usage: When opening [the item], it should be opened in the presence of a designated personnel as a general rule." 3. Ensure that the 2.7 filtration material is free from debris and other foreign matter prior to use, and filter it through a sieve as needed. 3. "2.8 The moisture content of the primer and substrate for the dry coating shall be dried after treatment and sufficient curing period, depending on the type of coating and the material of the substrate. If the appropriate moisture content is not specified in the specifications, check that the moisture content is 8% or less and then proceed to the next process." 3. 2.9 Unpainted Areas (1) Unless otherwise specified, finished metal surfaces such as plated surfaces, stainless steel, chrome plating, copper, tin, or materials finished with similar metals shall not be painted. (2) Moving parts of moving items and labels, including mechanical and electrical components such as valves, damper actuators, sensor motors, and blower shafts, shall not be painted unless otherwise instructed. However, labels shall not be painted. 3. 2.10 Paint Samples (1) Submit paint samples and painted samples to obtain the approval of the responsible person regarding color, gloss, etc. (2) Preserve the paint samples and painted samples so that they do not discolor. (3) However, the dimensions of the sample size shall be in accordance with the instructions of the responsible person, but the following dimensions are recommended. ① For steel substrates, they shall be 300×300mm in size and shall meet the required level of color, gloss, and texture of the color. Submit 2 samples painted with undercoats, midcoats, and topcoats, divided so that the painted surface appears at 10 mm intervals. ② For mortar and concrete substrates, they shall be 100×100mm in size and have different finishes and colors. Submit 2 samples painted with putty, undercoat paint, and topcoat paint, divided so that the painted surface appears at 10 mm intervals. ③ For wooden substrates, the painted samples painted on the wood surface shall be 100×200mm in size, showing the natural state of the wood surface, and submit 2 samples painted with undercoats, midcoats, and topcoats in order, divided so that the painted surface appears at 10 mm intervals. 3. 2.11 Paint Mixing and Mixing Location (1) The paint shall be adjusted within the mixing specifications to be suitable for application, considering factors such as the density, absorbency, and temperature rise of the base surface. (2) As a principle, the paint must be shaken thoroughly before mixing to prevent sediment from settling in the container. (3) Paint mixing shall be carried out in a designated area by the responsible personnel and under the supervision of the responsible personnel. 3. 2.12 Painting Equipment (1) Brushes and rollers shall be selected based on the properties of the paint being used and the surface being painted. (2) Trowels (putty knives) and gauges shall be selected based on the properties of the paint being used and the surface being painted. (3) Spraying equipment shall use a spray gun designed for painting. When using lacquer-type paints, the nozzle diameter should be considered. 1.0∼ 1.5mm, the air pressure of the spray is 0.2∼ The standard is 0.4N/mm², and the pressure should be adjusted appropriately depending on the viscosity of the material used. The compressed air used in the spray gun must be free of oil, moisture, and dust, and the air pressure must be maintained during use. Provide an appropriate device to prevent an increase of more than 0.02N/mm². The coating itself is under high pressure. 1 There is also an airless spray method that pressurizes the coating to around 4.7N/mm² and discharges it through a small nozzle for spraying. The airless spray nozzle assembly is... 0.02∼ "A thickness of 0.1mm is used, and the coating thickness can be increased as the value increases." 3. 2.13 Painting (1) Painting shall follow the manufacturer's instructions for the specified dry film thickness and application method of the coating, and be applied evenly to prevent defects such as blushing, spotting, running, wrinkling, foaming, and brush marks. However, for some coatings, such as oil stains and water repellents, which are difficult to form a film, the required amount of coating shall be confirmed. (2) In the painting process, the distinction between "coat" and "coat number" means, for example, that if a topcoat (1 coat) is specified, the topcoat shall be applied only once, and if a topcoat (2 coats) is specified, it means applying one more coat on top of the previously applied once. Also, if a topcoat (2 coats) is specified, the topcoat shall be applied once and then applied consecutively once more for a total of two coats. 3. Exercise caution to prevent contamination and damage to the beam transfer surface and surrounding environment, and perform protective covering work as needed using protective materials (such as plastic sheeting, tape, paper, and tarpaulins). 3. Each 2.15 inspection square process requires the responsible person's inspection and approval. 3. 2.16 Orderliness, Tidiness, and Disaster Prevention (1) The area around mixing and work spaces shall be kept clean and tidy, and dust such as wood shavings and paper shall not be allowed to scatter. (2) Used sandpaper, empty paint cans, curing films, etc., shall also be cleaned and disposed of in designated areas. (3) When handling flammable paints, open flames shall be strictly prohibited. Rags and other materials soaked with paint may spontaneously ignite due to the accumulation of oxidation heat, and there is a risk of fire due to welding work in the vicinity, so they should be stored in a safe place and the waste materials should be promptly disposed of in a designated area outside the site. 3. 2.17 Environment and Weather Conditions. Painting work or the curing period of coatings should not be carried out without the approval of the responsible personnel if the environmental and weather conditions at the painting location are as follows and good painting results cannot be expected. (1) When the temperature at the painting location is low, the humidity is high, and ventilation is insufficient, making the painting and drying unsuitable; when the ambient temperature is below 5 ℃ or the relative humidity exceeds 85%; when it is snowing, raining, or foggy. However, exceptions apply if separately indicated in the materials or the manufacturer's specifications. *. The surface temperature should be higher than the dew point to prevent moisture condensation. (2) When droplets, dust, etc. are likely to adhere to the coating film due to snowfall, strong wind, excessive ventilation, or dirtiness of the painting location. (3) When other work in the vicinity interferes with the painting work or there is a risk of damage to the coating film. 3.3 Construction Process 3. 3.1 Surface Preparation (1) Anti-Corrosion Coating ① For the initial anti-corrosion coat, it is generally recommended to apply it at the fabrication shop before assembly, unless chemical treatment is not performed, in which case it should be applied immediately after rust removal. However, if it is unavoidable to apply the coating after assembly, apply one coat to the surfaces that tightly adhere upon assembly, and 1-2 coats to the surfaces where anti-corrosion coating after assembly is difficult, applying them before assembly. Pre-assembly coating must be applied using products with a form approval (for welding workability) or, if welding is required during assembly, the areas to be welded should not be coated. ② After delivery to the site, remove welding spatter or foreign matter and apply 1-2 coats of anti-corrosion coating. However, if coating after installation is not possible, apply the coating before installation. ③ The type of base material, the manufacturer, and the product specifications shall comply with the corresponding standards, and the method of immersion coating may be used with the approval of the supervisor. (2) Putty Application ① Select putty materials suitable for the base material (wood, concrete, steel, etc.) and the type of finishing coat. ② According to the condition of the base material, fill the recessed holes, voids, cracks, and gaps with hole filler putty using a wooden or steel float, applying as thinly as possible. After drying, finish with abrasive paper (P160~180). ③ Repeat filling and smoothing 1-3 times as needed until the surface is flat. ④ However, the perimeter of eaves, scales, etc. may be omitted if it does not interfere. ⑤ Do not sand the putty with abrasive paper before it is completely dry. (3) Sealing Primer ① When applying a color coat to a base material with uneven absorbency, such as pine or fir, apply a sealing primer. ② Apply the sealing primer evenly with a brush or spray it evenly 1-2 times with a spray gun. (4) Coloring ① The coloring method shall be applied by brush, and after partial drying, wipe off excess coloring agent with a brush and soft cloth to remove color streaks. ② After drying, inspect the coated surface for severe color streaks and rework using the same method as described above if necessary. (5) Eyeing ① Apply the eyeing agent thoroughly by rubbing it with a stiff bristle brush (pig bristle brush) or a wooden/steel float into the residual pores of the wood grain, and wipe off any excess. When it is semi-dry with remaining tackiness, rub it with a nylon or hemp cloth in a 360° rotation and then wipe it with a soft cloth. ② Ensure that no eyeing agent remains on ears, door frames, and door panels. When eyeing is performed without a color coat, wait for the eyeing agent to dry completely and then lightly rub the coated surface with abrasive paper (P240) to remove any remaining eyeing agent. ③ When coloring is performed before eyeing, wipe off any excess eyeing agent with a cloth without sanding, taking care not to peel off the color coat layer. (6) Sanding ① Sanding includes dry sanding and wet sanding, but dry sanding is generally used in architectural coatings. ② After removing dirt and other foreign matter from the base, lightly sand the surface along the wood grain or in straight or elliptical patterns with the appropriate abrasive paper. Sanding should not be performed until the coating film has sufficiently elapsed and dried. ③ The abrasive materials and sanding methods to be used are as follows: a. Immerse KS L 6001 P320~P400 grade soft abrasive or pumice stone powder in about 5 times the amount of water and apply it to a woven felt or cloth. b. Use P320~P400 water-resistant abrasive paper, attach a backing of cork or rubber, and sand while wetting the surface. ④ When wetting the sanding area, be careful not to wet unnecessary areas all at once. ⑤ Sand until the surface is parallel to the wood grain, sufficiently flat, and the gloss is removed. After sanding, remove sanding debris from the surface with a sponge or sea sponge soaked in clear water, wash again with a squeezed-dry sponge, and then thoroughly wipe off moisture with a buffer or vinyl sponge. If the surface treatment is wet sanding, allow it to dry sufficiently for 2 hours or more before proceeding to the next step. 3. 3.2 Surface Preparation (1) General Surface Preparation ① Remove all rust, harmful foreign matter (dust, oil, tar, mortar, plaster, cement mortar), and deteriorated old coatings completely. ② Repair imperfections in the surface (such as holes, cracks, deformations, knots, and uneven absorption) to create a suitable surface for painting. ③ Treat the surface to prevent the effects of substances that may bleed or leach out (such as moisture, oil, resin, acid, and alkali). ④ Take necessary measures, such as sanding, to ensure proper adhesion of the coating. ⑤ Protect unpainted areas with masking or other methods to prevent paint from adhering before surface preparation or painting. ⑥ The type of surface preparation process (substrate type, surface preparation method) is shown in the table. Follow section 3.3-1, and in the absence of specific instructions for the type of material, use Grade 3 for steel surfaces, Grade 2 or 3 for galvanized surfaces, and Grade 2 for surfaces of precious metals and copper alloys. Table. 3.3-1 Surface Preparation Coating Method		Surface Type			Coating Type			Application Method			Wood surface, plaster surface, mortar surface, concrete surface			Type 1			Partial putty treatment			Type 2			Full putty treatment			Type 3			Seam putty treatment			Steel surface			Type 1			When performing phosphate treatment			Type 2			When applying metal surface primer			Type 3			Ordinary metal			Galvanized steel surface			Type 1			When applying metal surface primer			Type 2			When applying a solution of zinc sulfate			Type 3			For outdoor use exposed to wind and rain			Non-ferrous metals and copper alloys			Type 1			When performing phosphate treatment			Type 2			When applying metal surface primer	⑦ However, when applying vinyl-based coatings, the steel surface shall be Type 2 and the galvanized steel surface shall be Type 1. For industrial coatings dried at temperatures of 100 ℃ or higher, Type 1 (phosphate treatment) shall be applied. (2) Wood surface preparationWood coating is determined by the surface preparation, similar to metal coating. Since the wood surface varies depending on the type of wood and felling time, the appropriate method should be selected in advance according to the material.① ProcessThe standard for the process of wood surface preparation, coating, surface treatment, drying time, and coating amount is shown in the table. Follows Table according to 3.3-2. **3.3-2 Wood Surface Priming Process**

| Process | Content | Surface Treatment | Drying Time |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | Water Removal | Removal of contaminants and foreign substances, cleaning with gasoline or thinner |  |
| 2 | Resin Treatment | Scraping off resin, cauterization with a soldering iron, wiping with gasoline |  |
| 3 | Sanding | Sanding with P120~150 grit sandpaper to remove planer marks, cross-grain, and dents |  |
| 4 | Knot Filling | Selac varnish | Apply twice with a brush around the knot; more than 1 hour per coat |
| 5 | Hole Filling | Putty for hole filling | Fill cracks, holes, gaps, and recessed areas; more than 24 hours |

② The extent of wood surface priming shall generally be performed meticulously for interior parts and in accordance with the instructions of the responsible person, depending on the type of coating, coating area, coating environment, wood species, and surface shape. Wood sanding shall be performed in two stages: surface sanding and finish sanding.

a. Protruding nails on the surface shall be punched in with a punch to prevent damage to the surrounding area, and zinc putty shall be applied if there is a risk of rust.

b. Dust, dirt, and foreign substances shall be removed and cleaned without damaging the wood, and if necessary, washed with tap water or hot water.

c. Oils, other debris, etc. shall be wiped off and cleaned with gasoline or thinner.

d. Planer marks, cross-grain, and dents shall be removed by sanding with sandpaper (P120~240) according to the material of the base, and then sanded again with P240 sandpaper to prevent the surface and edges from becoming blurred and to ensure that the material of the soft part is not damaged and is leveled. However, for exterior parts such as eaves and scales, sanding may be omitted if there is no impediment.

e. Melted resin shall be scraped off with a knife or trowel, and parts with a lot of resin (e.g., around the knot) shall be heated with a soldering iron to melt the resin and wiped with gasoline.

f. For knot filling, apply Selac varnish once with a brush around the knot and parts where resin may come out (e.g., the pith of a three-needle pine), and apply a second coat after drying.

g. Cracks, wormholes, recesses, joints, and gaps in siding shall be filled with hole filling putty to make the surface flat.

h. In the case of transparent coating (varnish, clear lacquer, etc.), if there are severe color stains, dirt, or discoloration on the base surface, a bleaching agent may be used to bleach as necessary. When preparing the bleaching solution, use lukewarm water and apply it with a brush or sponge before it cools. After bleaching, wash with hot water and dry completely. For oak, sand flat with P100 grit sandpaper backed with rubber or cork. If necessary, sand flat with P320 waterproof sandpaper and kerosene. Otherwise, follow the instructions of the responsible person.

Notes:
1) Concrete surface treatment shall be calculated separately according to the sketch treatment method, design documents, and the instructions of the responsible personnel.
2) The entire surface treatment of PC panels shall be performed separately according to the instructions of the superintendent. However, when applying vinyl-based paints or synthetic resin emulsion paints, the substrate shall be cured for 3 weeks (21 days).

② Method
a. The substrate material shall be sufficiently dried for approximately 28 days or more under a temperature of 20℃ (with a surface moisture content of 7% or less), and the alkalinity should ideally be in a state of pH 9 or less.
b. Removal of contaminants and adherends shall be performed with caution to avoid damaging the substrate.
c. Areas with cracks, holes, etc., in the substrate shall be primed with water and then patched with gypsum putty. After drying, the surface shall be smoothed with sandpaper.
d. When preparing the substrate surface to receive a matte finish and special coating, the substrate surface should be roughened according to the properties of the coating.
e. Concrete floors planned for special coatings should be washed with a 5% hydrochloric acid solution, or other specialized cleaning agents, rinsed with water, and then neutralized with ammonia or other rinsing agents. Alternatively, sandblasting can be used. 3. 3.3 Coating Methods (1) Brushes and Rollers - Use brushes and rollers appropriate for the properties of the coating material and the surface to be coated. ① Brush Coating - Brush coating should generally be applied evenly and parallel, paying particular attention to color boundaries, corners, etc., based on the amount of coating material. Ensure a smooth finish to prevent defects such as streaks, runs, sags, bubbles, and brush marks. ② Roller Coating - Roller coating is faster than brush coating. However, maintaining a consistent film thickness like brush coating is very difficult, so pay special attention to rough or uneven surfaces. (2) Trowels (Putty Knives) and Trowels - Use trowels and trowels appropriate for the properties of the coating material and the surface to be coated. ① Trowel Coating - Trowel coating is primarily used to fill or smooth out irregularities, holes, and gaps in the surface, typically with high-viscosity putty or filler, and excess coating is scraped off to create a smooth finish. ② Leveling Coating - Leveling coating is used for self-leveling coating applications. The coating material, calculated based on the coating area and film thickness, is poured onto the floor, and the thickness is adjusted by scraping with a trowel. (3) Spray Coating Method ① Spray Equipment - Use a spray gun for coating. For lacquer-type coatings, the nozzle diameter. 1.0~ 1.5mm, the air pressure of the spray is 0.2~ The standard is 0.4N/mm², and it should be adjusted appropriately depending on the viscosity of the material being used. The compressed air used in the spray gun must be free of oil, moisture, and dust, and the air pressure must be maintained during use. Provide appropriate devices to prevent increase exceeding 0.02N/mm². The coating material itself is under high pressure. 1 There is also an airless spray method where the coating is pressurized to around 4.7N/mm² and discharged through a small outlet to spray it like a mist. The airless spray nozzle team is... 0.02~ Items with a thickness of 0.1mm are used, and the film thickness can be increased as the value increases. ② Spray Coating Method The standard spraying distance from the spray coating surface is 300mm, which can be adjusted depending on the pressure. When spraying, ensure a smooth, even surface and always move parallel while overlapping approximately 1/3 of the spray width for each pass. The spray direction for each coat should be perpendicular to the previous coat. Each coat of air spray should be applied to a thickness equivalent to brush coating, and the film thickness should not be applied in two coats at once. Airless spray coating allows for a thicker film in a single coat and can cover a large area in a short time. For solvent-free, rapid-hardening coatings, using a high-temperature, high-pressure collision mixing spray can complete the coating and drying process quickly. (4) Paint Filtration It is a principle to filter the paint with a sieve before use. The sieve shall comply with KS A 5101-1, 2, and 3, and table. Adopts 3.3-9 as the standard. Sanding for each process shall be performed after the coating film of the bottom coat is dry, and the grit of the sandpaper shall be in accordance with the coating process specified in each section.a. Generally, sanding shall be performed thoroughly for windows, doors, furniture, etc., and omitted for general structures and exterior scales, siding, eaves, etc., where the finish is not high-grade.b. Painting, drying, and sanding shall be performed each time as a principle, and smaller grit sandpaper shall be used as the finish coat approaches, and performed thoroughly in sequence.(6) Primer (including anti-corrosion), intermediate coat, and top coat painting regulations. 3. Consistent with 3.2 (1) and (2), when applying opaque coatings, the color of each coat layer in the undercoat, intermediate coat, and topcoat process can be differentiated if possible to determine the number of coat layers. (7) Safety coating work is not performed at a fixed location but is characterized by on-site mobile work. Therefore, to maximize work efficiency, workers must be familiar with the work and adhere to the following safety precautions: ① Coating materials shall be stored in a safe area protected from fire. ② Painting work shall not be performed near electrical motors of rectifier type, and explosion-proof devices must be used when performing surface treatment and operating coating equipment. ③ Solvent handling and coating application must be performed only on surfaces that are free from heat. ④ In the event of an accident, report immediately for first aid, and explosion-proof lights and fail-safe switches shall be used in the coating storage warehouse. ⑤ The work area must always be kept clean and organized. ⑥ Safety helmets, safety belts, safety glasses, dust masks, and other personal protective equipment shall always be prepared and worn during work. ⑦ Fire prevention equipment shall always be placed and used around the work area. 3.4 Coating Process by Material 3. 4.1 Water-Based Coating (1) The grade of the water-based coating shall be classified as interior, exterior grade 1, and exterior grade 2, depending on the type of coating method, coating type, application area, and number of coats. For exterior coatings, grade 1 products should be used to ensure durability, and if grade 2 products are used, products that meet the required quality standards should be used. (4) Precautions

① When applying natural drying coating, avoid applying it too thickly, as it can impair internal drying. The optimal film thickness for one coat is approximately 20~30㎛.

② Using lacquer thinner can reduce gloss and cause whitening or sagging.

③ After use, be sure to close the lid tightly to prevent air from entering the container and store it in a shaded place.

Sanding methods for primer and intermediate coats(a) Sand the surface to be smooth and be careful not to grind away the primer coating.(b) Sand the intermediate coat to make the surface smooth and be careful not to grind away the lacquer primer coating. As much as possible, remove the lacquer sealer coating.b. Topcoat(a) If humidity is high and there is a risk of whitening on the coating surface, reduce the lacquer thinner by 30% or less and replace it with a retarder thinner. Do not apply paint when the humidity is 85% or higher.(b) Even with dark colors, if gloss is required, reduce the lacquer colored paint by 20% or less and replace it with a clear lacquer. 3. (3) Application Method
① When applying varnish, use a varnish brush and move it parallel to the wood grain, and apply as much as possible with a single brushstroke. Lightly brush away any excess varnish left on the end of the brush with a brush.
② Varnish application is especially susceptible to humidity. Do not apply when the humidity is 85% or higher.
③ Ensure adequate ventilation, and wear protective gear when applying in a confined space.

(4) Varnish Repainting
① When the coating is severely aged. Remove all imperfections such as cracks, blisters, peeling, and dirt from the previous coating using a remover.
a. If a solvent-based remover is used, clean thoroughly with gasoline. If an alkaline remover is used, wash with an acid or other neutralizing agent.
b. After removing the base material, dry it thoroughly and clean it with abrasive paper. If necessary, apply staining or wood filler, and then apply the coating according to the previous process and method.
② When the coating is not severely aged. If there are no cracks or peeling in the existing coating, but only the gloss has faded, sand with sandpaper (P240∼P320) and then apply the coating according to the previous process and method. 3. 4.10 Oil Stain Coating (1) The coating method for oil stain coating varies depending on the type of finish and the materials used, as shown in the table. (7) Precautions ① Water-soluble antifungal coatings may crack if applied below 5℃, so avoid application at these temperatures and store them to prevent freezing. ② As a bio-coating with biological functions, mixing it with general coatings will impair the antifungal effect, so caution is advised. ③ Whitening or blistering is likely to occur under high humidity and temperature conditions, so the optimal temperature and relative humidity are 15-25℃ and below 85%, respectively. ④ If a sterilization treatment of the substrate is necessary (when mold is present), use a 20% sodium hypochlorite solution or a 20% ethanol solution, thoroughly wetting the substrate with a brush or roller, then rinse with water and allow it to dry completely. ⑤ If the substrate contains oil or moisture, gelling may occur, resulting in poor adhesion. Therefore, ensure the substrate is thoroughly dry before applying the coating. ⑥ Use only the specified thinner. For polyurethane intermediates, observe the recoat time to ensure good intercoat adhesion. ⑦ Hardeners are potentially explosive, so store them in a sealed area away from direct sunlight. ⑧ Two-component polyurethane coatings offer good workability but are toxic, so wear adequate ventilation equipment and a protective mask during application. ⑨ Before applying each coating, mix the base and hardener in the specified ratio for approximately 4-5 minutes until thoroughly and uniformly blended. ⑩ Polyurethane intermediates should be applied rapidly, considering the leveling of construction seams (within 20 minutes at 20℃). ⑪ Surfaces treated with concrete hardeners should be surface-cleaned by shot blasting, grinding, or with a dilute acid, then thoroughly rinsed with tap water and allowed to dry completely. Before applying the coating, be sure to check the adhesion of the coating to the surface. When performing acid treatment, wear protective gear such as rubber boots, rubber gloves, and a mask. ⑫ Cracks or unevenness on the surface should be V-shaped, coated, and dried, then treated with putty to adjust the surface to be smooth. ⑬ Mixed coatings should be used within the pot life, and the full performance of the coating film will be achieved 7 days after application at 20℃. Do not apply the coating if the temperature is below 5℃ or the relative humidity is above 85%. 3. "4.20 Other coating work (1) Fire-resistant coating work shall comply with KCS 41 43 02."
